BIG SQUAD IN MEET

Many Entries For the Event To
Be Held By Georgetown
University
Johns Hopkins will be represented
by a large squad in the meet to be
held by George Washington University in Washington on February 5.
When the first race is called there
will be an even dozen Black and Blue
sprinters on the floor, and when the
points are summed up at the end of
the meet Johns Hopkins should he
Close to the top.
The men are working hard every
day under the supervision of Coach
Hoffman and Captain Stollenwerck
and are fast rounding into shape.
"Freddie" Lee, the sophomore, who
ran away from all his competitors in
the half and the mile in the interclass
meet held recently in the Cage, is
almost sure to score in these events
in Washington. He has been training hard since the interclass meet,
and althouffh his best time has not
been announced it is known to be
very near the Cage record for the
distance. This means a great deal
when it is noted that "Polly" Brenton, "Mitch" Griffith and "Dutch"
Prever. all &stance men of the first
class, have trained in the Cage.
Merrick will be in the half with
Lee, and the pair should give a good
account of themselves. In the mile
Lee will have as running mates
"Dutch" Breyer and "Johnny" Reeside, both veterans at the game.
Breyer is the S. A. A. cross-country
champion, and Reeside has been a
member of the championship crosscountry team for the last two years.
1-Torrax and Morton, medical students, are both entered in the 50yard dash and the 50-yard high hurdles. TTorrax captained the Williams
track team in his senior year there.
Morton played end on the football
team this year and is well known to
Hopkinr rooters.
Tappan will also start in the high
hurdles, and great things are expecterl of him. He was one of the best
hurdlers on the smiad last year, and
he has shown big improvement. The
corrulete list of Hopkins entries is:
50-yard Dash — Morton, Horrax,
Stollenwerck.
50-yard Hurdles — Morton, Horrax, Tappan.
440-yard Dash — Hering, Chandler. Stollenwerck, Sigmund, Brown.
88o-vard Run — Lee, Merrick.
One-mile Run — Lee, Breyer, Reeside.
HiFdi Jump — I-Torrax, Tappan.

STATUE OF
HOPKINS

JOHNS

In March, 1905, a movement was
started to erect a monument at Homewood to Johns Hopkins, as a suitable testimony of his philanthropy.
At the time a special committee consisting of Mr. Bernard M. Baker,
chairman; President Ira Remsen, of
the University; the late Dr. Daniel
C. Gilman, Mr.R. Brent Keyser, Gen.
John Gill, Mr. Theodore Marburg,.
Hon. Charles J. Bonaparte and Mr.
Josias Pennington, was appointed and
up to the present date $10,000 has
been raised for the purpose. It is
hoped that the city will appropriate
$15,000 toward the fund; then the
Municipal Art Society is expected to
raise the balance, about $15,000.
The design of Mr. Hans Schuler,
the local sculptor, has been accepted
by the committee in charge of the
work. It is not likely, however, that
Mr. Schuler will be authorized to
proceed until the full amount has
been subscribed. The statue itself
will be of bronze, and the design has
been much admired. Mr. Hopkins is
portrayed in a standing position in
a characteristic and easy attitude. The
statue is as true to life as possible
without any attempt at idealization.
The statue will he erected in front
of the old Carroll Mansion, the present site of the Boys' Country School,
and will face on Charles street.
The photograph reproduced in today's issue was secured for publication in the News-Letter through the
courtesy of Mr. Theodore Marburg
and the sculptor.

In many colleges it has been found
advisable to establish a system of authorized "cuts" for the benefit of undergraduates. Under this arrangement a student is given permissi' •
to be absent from class a certain
number of times during a term. The
absence is noted, but no unfavorable
report is made on the student's record, and absolutely no discount is
imposed upon his mark. Occasions
arise when absence from class becomes a necessity. Under the present system the student is expected to
to call upon the instructor as soon
as possible and explain his absence.
As it is no longer permissible to
"bring a note from home," the resulting interview is balle to he painful to the student. if not to the instructor. Permission to he absent
from each class two or three times in
each term is often a relief to a student wishing to finish some work before undergoino. a written quiz or examination. The authorized cut is
nndoul tedlv a relief to both instructor
and student. The atmosphere is less
like that of the schoolroom, without
presenting too great an opportunity
for the habitual truant.

The subject of "International Law"
Will be discussed by Dr. James Brown
Scott, of the Department of State,
Washington. Dr. Scott has had wide
experience as a lawyer and teacher
of law. His training in the subject,
begun at Harvard, was carried on at
Paris, Berlin, and Heidelberg. After
Practising in the West, he gave his
tim e to teaching, and has bccn at one
time or another a member of the
faculty of law in the following institutions: Los Angeles Law School,
University of Illinois, Columbia University, University of Chicago, and
George \Vashington University. Ti.
Will be remembered that in 1903 he
gave a series of lectures in this University, entitled: "The Hague Peace
Conferences of 1899-1907;" these lectures have since been published in
two volumes. Dr. Scott is one of
the editars of the American Journal
of International Law and has publishamong other standard books.
"Cases on International Law" and
"Cases on Quasi-Contracts."
Economists will be interested in a
course of lectures by Mr. Logan G.
McPherson, of New York, on "Railway Transportation." As a practical
business man, and not less as a writer
'311 economic topics. Mr. McPherson
IS widely known. He was for many
Years connected with various Pitts-

burg coal companies, and at one time

and Consolidation Companies he resided in Baltimore. Besides being a
recognized authority in the railroad
world, he has published several books
on various economic questions, including: "The Monetary and Banking Problem," and "Evolution and
Economics." He has lectured in this
University since 1905.
An authori'atiye discussion of sociological problems will be given by
Dr. John M. Glenn. formerly of 13a1timore, but now living in New York.
His subject, "Problems of Relief," is
one that his position as Secretary and
Director of the Russell Sage Foundation particularly qualifies him to discuss.
Baron Serge Korff, Professor of
Public law in the University of Finland. will lecture on "Modern Russian History and Law." Baron Korff
is quite prominent politically in his
own country, and he can speak with a
direct first-hand knowledge of conditions and events in the Russian Empire.
Dr. Charles Wardell Stiles, of the
United States Bureau of Public
Health, is to lecture before the Medical School upon the subject of Medical Zoology. To the public Dr.Stiles is
probably best known as the discoverer
of the hook worm, and is the chairman of the committee that is to use
the million dollars donated by Rockefeller to exterminate it. To scien-

Dr. Christine Ladd Franklin, of
New York, will deliver her usual lectures on "Symbolic Logic" and the
"Theory of Color Vision." Mrs.
Franklin, after her graduation from
Vassar, became a fellow of this University in the mathematical department. under Professor Sylvester. She
has also studied at Goettingen and at
Berlin. Her theory of color vision
has attracted much attention both in
this country and abroad. She is an
assistant editor of the Psychological
Review and was a member of the
editorial staff of Baldwin's Dictionary of Philosophy and Psychologyy.

Dear Sir:
In writing- this it is my pleasure to
make a few points tentative to the
proposed Honor System. The system may have several defects and
many points which can be improved
upon, but considering it as a whole,
I think the adoption would be a vast
improvement and a monument of lasting fame to our University.
Mr. McCabe and myself have very
carefully considered all points both
pro and con. We have investigated
the conditions at the University of
Virginia, Princeton University, and
at Williams College. A system very
similar to the above is in vogue at
each of these institutions.
At
Virginia the system has been in constant use since the early days of the
school. At Princeton it has worked
equally well. At Williams College,
since 1896, the year of its introduction, it has gone on without a hitch.
If the system has met with such success at each of these first-class schools,
why should it not succeed at Johns
Hopkins?
In an official capacity the faculty
have not committed themselves, but
individually every member with whom
I have spoken has been eager for the
adoption of the same. The faculty
will not pass upon the proposed Honor System until each of the four
classes have decided whether or not
they are in favor of its adoption.
I sincerely trust that the plan will
receive a favorable reception by all
the classes and that the Honor System
will soon be in use at our University.
If for any reason the students see
fit not to accept the proposed system,
I think some other should be adopted. Indeed, I think it would be a serious reflection upon any University
of our standing for its undergraduate
members to turn down an honor system, without proposing and accepting
a better system in its stead.
I further believe that the press
representatives in our midst should
not print anything relative to the proposed Honor System until this or
some other system is adopted. For
in case no honor system is introduced, after all the notoriety attendant thereto, the reflection will be very
adverse to the reputation of Johns
Hopkins.
I thank you for your valuable space
and commit myself.
Yours very truly,
Edmund B. Clary.

Johns Hopkins will be represented
by a large squad in the meet to be
held by George Washington University in Washington on February 5.
When the first race is called there
will be an even dozen Black and Blue
sprinters on the floor, and when the
points are summed up at the end of
the meet Johns Hopkins should he
Close to the top.
The men are working hard every
day under the supervision of Coach
Hoffman and Captain Stollenwerck
and are fast rounding into shape.
"Freddie" Lee, the sophomore, who
ran away from all his competitors in
the half and the mile in the interclass
meet held recently in the Cage, is
almost sure to score in these events
in Washington. He has been training hard since the interclass meet,
and althouffh his best time has not
been announced it is known to be
very near the Cage record for the
distance. This means a great deal
when it is noted that "Polly" Brenton, "Mitch" Griffith and "Dutch"
Prever. all &stance men of the first
class, have trained in the Cage.
Merrick will be in the half with
Lee, and the pair should give a good
account of themselves. In the mile
Lee will have as running mates
"Dutch" Breyer and "Johnny" Reeside, both veterans at the game.
Breyer is the S. A. A. cross-country
champion, and Reeside has been a
member of the championship crosscountry team for the last two years.
1-Torrax and Morton, medical students, are both entered in the 50yard dash and the 50-yard high hurdles. TTorrax captained the Williams
track team in his senior year there.
Morton played end on the football
team this year and is well known to
Hopkinr rooters.
Tappan will also start in the high
hurdles, and great things are expecterl of him. He was one of the best
hurdlers on the smiad last year, and
he has shown big improvement. The
corrulete list of Hopkins entries is:
50-yard Dash — Morton, Horrax,
Stollenwerck.
50-yard Hurdles — Morton, Horrax, Tappan.
440-yard Dash — Hering, Chandler. Stollenwerck, Sigmund, Brown.
88o-vard Run — Lee, Merrick.
One-mile Run — Lee, Breyer, Reeside.

FOR

STATUE OF
HOPKINS

JOHNS

In March, 1905, a movement was
started to erect a monument at Homewood to Johns Hopkins, as a suitable testimony of his philanthropy.
At the time a special committee consisting of Mr. Bernard M. Baker,
chairman; President Ira Remsen, of
the University; the late Dr. Daniel
C. Gilman, Mr.R. Brent Keyser, Gen.
John Gill, Mr. Theodore Marburg,.
Hon. Charles J. Bonaparte and Mr.
Josias Pennington, was appointed and
up to the present date $10,000 has
been raised for the purpose. It is
hoped that the city will appropriate
$15,000 toward the fund; then the
Municipal Art Society is expected to
raise the balance, about $15,000.
The design of Mr. Hans Schuler,
the local sculptor, has been accepted
by the committee in charge of the
work. It is not likely, however, that
Mr. Schuler will be authorized to
proceed until the full amount has
been subscribed. The statue itself
will be of bronze, and the design has
been much admired. Mr. Hopkins is
portrayed in a standing position in
a characteristic and easy attitude. The
statue is as true to life as possible
without any attempt at idealization.
The statue will he erected in front
of the old Carroll Mansion, the present site of the Boys' Country School,
and will face on Charles street.
The photograph reproduced in today's issue was secured for publication in the News-Letter through the
courtesy of Mr. Theodore Marburg
and the sculptor.

In many colleges it has been found
advisable to establish a system of authorized "cuts" for the benefit of undergraduates. Under this arrangement a student is given permissi' •
to be absent from class a certain
number of times during a term. The
absence is noted, but no unfavorable
report is made on the student's record, and absolutely no discount is
imposed upon his mark. Occasions
arise when absence from class becomes a necessity. Under the present system the student is expected to
to call upon the instructor as soon
as possible and explain his absence.
As it is no longer permissible to
"bring a note from home," the resulting interview is balle to he painful to the student. if not to the instructor. Permission to he absent
from each class two or three times in
each term is often a relief to a student wishing to finish some work before undergoino. a written quiz or examination. The authorized cut is
nndoul tedlv a relief to both instructor
and student. The atmosphere is less
like that of the schoolroom, without

The subject of "International Law"
Will be discussed by Dr. James Brown
Scott, of the Department of State,
Washington. Dr. Scott has had wide
experience as a lawyer and teacher
of law. His training in the subject,
begun at Harvard, was carried on at
Paris, Berlin, and Heidelberg. After
Practising in the West, he gave his
tim e to teaching, and has bccn at one
time or another a member of the
faculty of law in the following institutions: Los Angeles Law School,
University of Illinois, Columbia University, University of Chicago, and
George \Vashington University. Ti.
Will be remembered that in 1903 he
gave a series of lectures in this University, entitled: "The Hague Peace
Conferences of 1899-1907;" these lectures have since been published in
two volumes. Dr. Scott is one of
the editars of the American Journal
of International Law and has publishamong other standard books.
"Cases on International Law" and
"Cases on Quasi-Contracts."
Economists will be interested in a
course of lectures by Mr. Logan G.
McPherson, of New York, on "Railway Transportation." As a practical
business man, and not less as a writer
'311 economic topics. Mr. McPherson
IS widely known. He was for many
Years connected with various Pitts-

burg coal companies, and at one time
whilb in business with the Fairmont
and Consolidation Companies he resided in Baltimore. Besides being a
recognized authority in the railroad
world, he has published several books
on various economic questions, including: "The Monetary and Banking Problem," and "Evolution and
Economics." He has lectured in this
University since 1905.
An authori'atiye discussion of sociological problems will be given by
Dr. John M. Glenn. formerly of 13a1timore, but now living in New York.
His subject, "Problems of Relief," is
one that his position as Secretary and
Director of the Russell Sage Foundation particularly qualifies him to discuss.
Baron Serge Korff, Professor of
Public law in the University of Finland. will lecture on "Modern Russian History and Law." Baron Korff
is quite prominent politically in his
own country, and he can speak with a
direct first-hand knowledge of conditions and events in the Russian Empire.
Dr. Charles Wardell Stiles, of the
United States Bureau of Public
Health, is to lecture before the Medical School upon the subject of Medical Zoology. To the public Dr.Stiles is

l-eing- received with such approval.
Perhaps, as a former business manager of your paper, I may be permitted to suggest that this would be
a very good scheme, and on that assumption, and also on the assumption that subscriptions would be acceptable, I had the following men
of 1002 sign the enclosed subscription

if you will permit a suggestion,would

orp-anizations? If you will keep the

January 25, 1910.
Mr. G. Ross Veazey.
Editor-in-Chief of The News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
In writing- this it is my pleasure to
make a few points tentative to the
proposed Honor System. The system may have several defects and
many points which can be improved
upon, but considering it as a whole,
I think the adoption would be a vast
improvement and a monument of lasting fame to our University.
Mr. McCabe and myself have very
carefully considered all points both
pro and con. We have investigated
the conditions at the University of
Virginia, Princeton University, and
at Williams College. A system very
similar to the above is in vogue at
each of these institutions.
At
Virginia the system has been in constant use since the early days of the
school. At Princeton it has worked
equally well. At Williams College,
since 1896, the year of its introduction, it has gone on without a hitch.
If the system has met with such success at each of these first-class schools,
why should it not succeed at Johns
Hopkins?
In an official capacity the faculty
have not committed themselves, but
individually every member with whom
I have spoken has been eager for the
adoption of the same. The faculty
will not pass upon the proposed Honor System until each of the four
classes have decided whether or not
they are in favor of its adoption.
I sincerely trust that the plan will
receive a favorable reception by all
the classes and that the Honor System
will soon be in use at our University.
If for any reason the students see
fit not to accept the proposed system,
I think some other should be adopted. Indeed, I think it would be a serious reflection upon any University
of our standing for its undergraduate
members to turn down an honor system, without proposing and accepting
a better system in its stead.
I further believe that the press
representatives in our midst should
not print anything relative to the proposed Honor System until this or
some other system is adopted. For
in case no honor system is introduced, after all the notoriety attendant thereto, the reflection will be very
adverse to the reputation of Johns
Hopkins.
I thank you for your valuable space
and commit myself.
Yours very truly,
Edmund B. Clary.
